original_title: A Really Low Level Guide To Doing Ethernet on an FPGA
original_content:
With so much of our day-to-day networking done wirelessly these days, it can be easy to forget about Ethernet. But its a useful standard and can be a great way to add a reliable high-throughput network link to your projects. To that end, [Robert Feranec] and [Stacy Rieck] whipped up a tutorial on how to work with Ethernet on FPGAs. 
As [Robert] explains, many people would like to transfer data from FPGA boards to somewhere else. That basically sums up why you might be interested in doing this. The duo spend over an hour stepping through doing Ethernet at a very low level, without using pre-existing IP blocks to make it easier. The video explains the basic architecture right down to the physical pins on the device and what they do, all the way up to the logic blocks inside the device that do all the protocol work.
If you just want to get data off an embedded project, you can always pull in some existing libraries to do the job. But if you want to really understand Ethernet, this is a great place to start. Theres no better way to learn than doing it yourself. Files are on GitHub for the curious.
title: FPGAでイーサネットを活用する方法
body: 日常的なネットワーキングが無線で行われている今日、Ethernetの重要性を忘れがちですが、高帯域ネットワークリンクをプロジェクトに追加する方法として便利です。FPGA上でのEthernetの扱い方についてのチュートリアルがGitHubに公開されています。
titles: FPGAでイーサネットを活用する方法
プロジェクトに信頼性の高いイーサネットリンクを追加する方法
イーサネットを低レベルから理解するチュートリアル
自作で学ぶイーサネットの基本アーキテクチャ
GitHubで公開されたイーサネット関連の資料
